newsitem.title: UK: Electrophoretics has licence for CJD test.
newsitem.headline: Electrophoretics has licence for CJD test.

text.p: Electrophoretics International Plc on Thursday confirmed that it has acquired a licence from the U.S. National Institute of Health to commercialise a diagnostic test for Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD).

Electrophoretics said it acquired a licence to commercialize a patent entitled "Method for Distinguishing Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease from Other Dementias," as discovered by Michael Harrington, Carl Merril, David Ascher and Dr. Carleton Gajdusek.

Electrophoretics said it is already able to test in vivo for CJD in patients with symptoms of the disease and has been working on the method of how to make the CJD test commercially available as soon as possible.
CJD is the human equivalent of BSE, better known as mad cow disease.
